All_Reported_Opinions_Cited_with_Shorten: extract every citation to a judicial opinion that includes a reporter or database citation (e.g., 123 F.3d 456; 789 U.S. 321; 2020 WL 4218003). Include the case name if it appears immediately before the citation (ignore signals like "see," "cf.," and commas); otherwise output the citation alone. Output one entry per opinion as "Case Name, Reporter/Database Citation," using shortened Bluebook form if applicable. Strip pincites and parentheticals; if parallel cites appear, keep only the first. Exclude id./supra/infra, docket-only references, slip opinions without a reporter/database cite, and non-case sources (statutes, rules, articles).
Appeal: identify whether any appeals are mentioned, including which parties filed the appeal and to which court and provide the extracted information. If applicable, clearly state the information using the following format: "Appeal: [parties] appealed to [court]." Try to be as completely as possible.
Cause_of_Action: extract the legal vehicle(s) used to bring the claims (the "how" of suing), such as statutes that create a private/enforcement right of action (e.g., 42 U.S.C. § 1983, Title II ADA, FTCA) or judge-made vehicles (e.g., Bivens). Do not include underlying rights (constitutional amendments or statutory rights), remedies (injunction, damages, declaratory relief), or procedural doctrines/rules (e.g., Rule 23, Ex parte Young, standing, immunity). Deduplicate repeats (e.g., list § 1983 once even if tied to multiple rights).
Class_Action_or_Individual_Plaintiffs: identify whether the case involves class action plaintiffs or individual plaintiffs. Clearly state the information using the following format: "Plaintiffs: Class Action" if it is a class action, or "Plaintiffs: Individual, described as [description]" if individual plaintiffs are involved.
Consolidated_Cases_Noted: identify whether any consolidated cases are mentioned and extract the crucial consolidated cases information as completely as possible.
Court_Rulings: identify the court’s decisions or orders mentioned in the documents and summarize each as a short, self-contained narrative entry. Focus on how the court ruled on key motions or issues, such as: granted/denied motions to dismiss, granted/denied summary judgment, issued preliminary injunctions or TROs, certified/denied class certification, or made other significant procedural or substantive rulings. For each ruling, state what motion or issue the court decided, how it ruled (e.g., granted, denied, etc.), who brought the motion (if clear), and the relevant date(s) if available. Do not just restate document titles; instead, write each entry so that a reader can understand what the court decided from that entry alone. Extract each ruling as a separate entry.
Date_of_Settlement: extract all settlement-related dates (each as a separate entry) such as execution/signing date(s), court approval date (if approved but not entered as an order), amendment dates, enforcement/retention dates without incorporation (e.g., court retains jurisdiction over the settlement but does not enter it as an order), and termination/expiration of the settlement agreement (if contractual). Do not include any date once the settlement (in whole or part) is incorporated into a judgment/order. Format each as: "[date]: [settlement event]."
Dates_of_All_Decrees: extract all decree-related dates (each as a separate entry) such as entry date, modification/amendment dates (of the order), suspension/stay dates, partial termination dates, and full termination/vacatur dates. Decrees include injunctions, consent decrees, or stipulated judgments/injunctions. If a settlement later becomes a court order (e.g., 'consent decree entered'), include the entry date of that order here (pre-entry settlement dates do not belong here). Do not include dates for non-decree items (e.g., private settlements not entered as orders). Format each as: "[date]: [decree event]."
Disputes_Over_Settlement_Enforcement: extract the disputes about enforcing a settlement (a negotiated agreement not entered as a court order)—e.g., motions to enforce/contempt or requests invoking retained jurisdiction—each as a separate entry with date, movant, issue, and outcome (or “pending”). Exclude any disputes over decrees (consent decrees, stipulated judgments/injunctions). Format each dispute as a separate entry.
Factual_Basis_of_Case: extract the facts or evidence upon which the case is built. These facts are essential in the legal process and are used to support legal claims or decisions. It typically includes: 1. Details of the relevant events—For example, what happened, when it happened, where it happened, and who was involved. 2. Evidence – Physical evidence, documentary records, witness testimonies, etc., that support these facts. 3. Background information—Context or explanatory facts that provide additional understanding.
Filing_Date: extract the case filing date—when the lawsuit was first initiated. Extract the crucial information as completely as possible.
First_and_Last_name_of_Judge: identify the first and last name of the judge(s) involved in the case and provide the extracted information. Example output format: [full name]. If the documents only mentioned the last name of the judge, only state the last name. If the documents only mentioned the first name of the judge, only state the first name. Do not include Supreme Court Justices.
How_Long_Decrees_will_Last: extract the duration of all decrees obligations (each as a separate entry). A 'decree' is any formal order or judgment issued by a court such as an injunction, consent decree, or stipulated judgment/injunction, as opposed to a negotiated agreement between parties. Only include obligations that are ordered by the court. Format each as: "[duration]: [decree obligation]."
How_Long_Settlement_will_Last: extract the duration of all settlements obligations (each as a separate entry). A 'settlement' is any negotiated agreement between parties that resolves a dispute, as opposed to a formal order or judgment issued by a court. Only include settlement obligations that are not incorporated into a court order or judgment. Format each as: "[duration]: [settlement obligation]."
Monitor_Reports: identify references to monitoring activities or compliance reviews mentioned in the documents. Extract concise information about: (1) what is being monitored, (2) key findings or compliance status if mentioned, (3) dates of monitoring activities if available. Focus on summarizing the monitoring outcomes rather than extracting entire reports. Format as brief statements like: 'Monitor found [compliance/non-compliance] with [specific requirement] as of [date]'. Limit to the most significant monitoring findings only.
Name_of_the_Monitor: identify whether a monitor was appointed and note the name of the monitor if mentioned.
Note_Important_Filings: identify the important filings or motions mentioned in the provided documents and summarize each as a short, self-contained narrative entry. Focus on key procedural filings such as motions for temporary restraining orders, preliminary injunctions, motions to dismiss, motions for summary judgment, etc. For each filing, state who filed it, what it asked the court to do, the relevant date(s) if available. Do not just list document titles; instead, write each entry so that a reader can understand what happened from that entry alone. Extract each filing as a separate entry.
Related_Cases_Listed_by_Their_Case_Code_: identify whether any related cases are listed by their case code number and extract the crucial consolidated cases information as completely as possible.
Remedy_Sought: extract what each party asks the court to grant, not what the court ordered or what the parties settled. Include both sides if the defendant seeks relief. List each requested remedy as its own entry. Format each as: 'Plaintiff: [remedy]' or 'Defendant: [remedy]'.
Significant_Terms_of_Decrees: extract the significant terms of decrees. 'Significant terms' means the substantive obligations ordered by the court. This includes consent decrees and stipulated judgments/injunctions because they are entered as court orders. Do not include terms that appear only in a settlement agreement unless those terms are expressly incorporated into (and thus ordered by) the court. Extract as completely as possible, with each term as a separate entry. If only part of a settlement is incorporated into an order, extract only the incorporated terms.
Significant_Terms_of_Settlement: extract the significant terms of settlements. 'Significant terms' means the substantive obligations the parties agree to in a settlement that is not entered as a court order. Do not list any terms the court ordered (such as those in consent decrees or stipulated judgments/injunctions). A settlement may be court-approved or enforced, but as long as it is not entered as an order, it is a settlement. Extract as completely as possible, with each term as a separate entry. If some terms are incorporated into an order, extract only the non-incorporated (purely contractual) terms.
Statutory_or_Constitutional_Basis_for_th: extract the substantive rights and sources of law allegedly violated (the 'what' was violated), such as specific constitutional provisions/clauses (e.g., Fourteenth Amendment — Equal Protection, First Amendment — Freedom of Association, Eighth Amendment) and statutory rights (e.g., ADA Title II, Rehab Act § 504). Do not include the cause-of-action vehicle itself (e.g., 42 U.S.C. § 1983), remedies (injunctive relief, damages), or purely procedural doctrines (Rule 23, Ex parte Young). Prefer clause-level detail when provided; if only the amendment or statute is named, list that. Break each distinct basis into its own entry.
Trials: extract information about all trials mentioned in the documents as completely as possible. The trial information includes things like scheduling, proceedings, outcomes, and any related motions or rulings.
Type_of_Counsel: identify the type(s) of counsel representing each side. Use brief category labels (e.g., private counsel, public interest nonprofit, government counsel, pro se) and include specific organizations (if applicable) in parentheses (e.g., Public interest nonprofit (ACLU)). If both sides are represented, format them as two entries: Plaintiff: ... and Defendant: .... If the type of counsel for a side is not clear from the documents, do not include an entry for that side.
Whether_the_Settlement_is_Court-enforced: identify whether the settlement (not entered as an order/judgment) is court-enforced. Answer Yes if the court explicitly retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement without incorporating it into an order/judgment (e.g., Kokkonen retention). Answer No if it’s a private agreement with no retained jurisdiction. Format the answer as: "[Yes/No]."
Who_are_the_Parties: identify the description of the parties involved. Provide details about each plaintiff and defendant, including any relevant positions or offices held if applicable. Extract each individual party as a separate entry in the extracted list. If there are multiple plaintiffs or multiple defendants, create a distinct entry for each person or entity. Each value should follow this format: "Plaintiff: [description]" or "Defendant: [description]". Try to be as complete as possible.
